items.title: tile function and " Heuristic to find points straddling tiles."
items.body:
I am slightly confused by this snippet of code from **def tile(lng, lat, zoom, truncate=False)**,
and the similar one regarding ytile.

```python
        xtile_a = math.floor((x - EPSILON) * Z2)
        xtile_b = math.floor((x + EPSILON) * Z2)
        if xtile_a != xtile_b:
            xtile = int(xtile_b)
        else:
            xtile = int(xtile_a)
```

It seems to me that the value in xtile_b will be always used, and that calculating xitle_a can be disregarded, or is there some floating point issue I am not seeing?

items.title: Utility function for NumPy Array Representation of Tile Coordinates
items.body:
Hi, Mapbox - thanks for this utility! It's been quite useful for me on a few projects.

One use case that I've had for it has been to generate rastered tilesets for variations on nearest-neighbor type algorithms with 2 dimensional geographic datasets. For these, it's been quite useful to be able to generate a 3D `numpy` array of shape (WIDTH, HEIGHT, 2) for representation of each pixel location in the tile. With this array I can then generate predictions from a K-NearestNeighbors model, mask the results of predictions for tile using `rasterio` tooling, etc. 

I thought it might be a useful functionality for other people in their projects, and would be happy to contribute to the codebase if you felt it was within scope of the `mercantile`. Code logic below. It does introduce a `numpy` dependency which may not be ok.

```
import mercantile
import numpy as np

def tile_to_matrix(tile: mercantile.Tile, WIDTH=256, HEIGHT=256) -> np.ndarray:
    bounds = mercantile.bounds(tile)
    x_domain = np.linspace(bounds.west, bounds.east, WIDTH)
    y_domain = np.linspace(bounds.north, bounds.south, HEIGHT)
    matrix = np.transpose(
        [np.tile(x_domain, len(y_domain)), np.repeat(y_domain, len(x_domain))]
    ).reshape((HEIGHT, WIDTH, 2))
    return matrix
```

another similarly useful function might be `get_affine_transform(tile: mercantile.Tile) ...` etc. for building the affine transforms for each tile from `rasterio` or `affine` packages.

items.title: 1.1.4 release
items.body: Bug fixes. Target date: 2020-04-28.

items.title: Inconsistent errors when Latitude is 90 vs. -90
items.body:
**TL;DR**: When Latitude is 90, resulting exception should be nearly identical to when Latitude is -90.

When calling mercantile.tile() when latitude is -90, a descriptive stack trace and error is raised:

```
>>> mercantile.tile(30, -90, 10, truncate=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mercantile/__init__.py", line 307, in _xy
    y = 0.5 - 0.25 * math.log((1.0 + sinlat) / (1.0 - sinlat)) / math.pi
ValueError: math domain error

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mercantile/__init__.py", line 331, in tile
    x, y = _xy(lng, lat, truncate=truncate)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mercantile/__init__.py", line 309, in _xy
    raise InvalidLatitudeError("Y can not be computed: lat={!r}".format(lat))
mercantile.InvalidLatitudeError: Y can not be computed: lat=-90
>>> 
```

However, when latitude is 90, a different (and less descriptive) error is raised:
```
>>> mercantile.tile(30, 90, 10, truncate=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mercantile/__init__.py", line 331, in tile
    x, y = _xy(lng, lat, truncate=truncate)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mercantile/__init__.py", line 307, in _xy
    y = 0.5 - 0.25 * math.log((1.0 + sinlat) / (1.0 - sinlat)) / math.pi
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero
>>> 
```
Given that the problem arises from Latitude being too large, "ZeroDivisionError" was unhelpful and took me time to unravel the root cause.

I would expect that the errors should be the same, and be helpful, providing the user actionable information regarding how to fix the error.

A fix for this bug would involve calling `mercantile.tile()`  with Lat = 90.0, resulting in a raised exception `mercantile.InvalidLatitudeError: Y can not be computed: lat=90`, consistent with the error raised by -90.

items.title: Split bounding box in n parts
items.body:
Currently I'd like to divide an existing bounding box [s,w,n,e] + Zoom level in `n` equal parts. So say in 4 parts. Is this possible with mercantile? 

The goal is to divide the bounding box, in order to render (to image) each individual part and stitch back together after.

items.title: bounding_tile issue
items.body:
> pip3 show mercantile
> Name: mercantile
> Version: 1.0.4

`bounding_tile` does not return the same tile that was used to create the bounding box.
```py
>>> tile = mercantile.Tile(x=69327, y=45014, z=17)
>>> bounds = mercantile.bounds(tile)
>>> mercantile.bounding_tile(*bounds)
Tile(x=2166, y=1406, z=12)
```
The documentation seems to indicate that the behavior described is unexpected: 

> Get the smallest tile containing a geographic bounding box


Questions:

Is this working as intended? 
Why is the zoom level so small?

items.title: mercantile.bounding_tile returns low zoom levels around specific lat/lng values
QuadKeyError should inherit from ValueError?
items.body:
Supplying an invalid quadkey (like "5") to `quadkey_to_tile` raises a QuadKeyError.  The purposes of the built-in ValueError is to specify that the type of the argument is correct, but it's an incorrect value.  This is the case for a quadkey of "5" (ie, a string that is not a valid quadkey).  I think Mercantile did this before.

This has an impact because code that is checking for ValueError will break (as happened for us).  Also, an error which doesn't inherit from ValueError has different semantics; code that is trying to handle incorrect input won't know what to do with QuadKeyError.

items.title: Problem arround 0
items.body:
Hi,

With this simple geojson (named as geo.geojson):

```geojson
{
    "type": "FeatureCollection",
    "features": [
        {
            "type": "Feature",
            "properties": {},
            "geometry": {
                "type": "Polygon",
                "coordinates": [
                    [
                        [
                            -1.109619140625,
                            50.968805734317804
                        ],
                        [
                            0.8074951171874999,
                            50.968805734317804
                        ],
                        [
                            0.8074951171874999,
                            51.82559340146247
                        ],
                        [
                            -1.109619140625,
                            51.82559340146247
                        ],
                        [
                            -1.109619140625,
                            50.968805734317804
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            }
        }
    ]
}
```

I've done this: 

```
$ cat geo.geojson | jq -c . | mercantile bounding-tile
[0, 0, 0]
```

And it's not the write answer.

I've got mercantile: 1.0.4 with python 3.6.7

items.title: improve documentation when passing in geojson
items.body:
can I add the advice from https://github.com/mapbox/mercantile/issues/64#issuecomment-337721427 to use `jq -s -c '.[0]'` when passing in GeoJSON to the cli tools? I can do a PR.

I got stuck on this with my pretty printed geojson, and only found the solution digging through closed tickets.

items.title: quadkey_to_tile doesn't handle empty quadkeys correctly.
items.body:
When calling `quadkey_to_tile('')`, the loop at [line 271](https://github.com/mapbox/mercantile/blob/master/mercantile/__init__.py#L271) is not traversed, which means `i` is not initialized, and L282 raises an `UnboundLocalError`.  It should either:
1. construct Tile(0, 0, 0), or
2. raise a ValueError if the zoom 0 tile is not supported (although constructing `Tile(0, 0, 0)` is valid).

I'm happy to make a PR for either choice if you have a preference.

items.title: mercantile tiles method is not idempotent
Should raise a ValueError when constructing an "invalid" tile?
items.body:
```python
import mercantile
x, y, z = 10, 0, 0
tile = mercantile.Tile(x, y, z)
mercantile.bounds(tile)
# LngLatBbox(west=3420.0, south=-85.0511287798066, east=3780.0, north=85.0511287798066)
```
I find this surprising. I expected to see a ValueError or similar exception being raised if trying to build a tile like this: at zoom level 0, the only valid x and y values (to my mind) are 0 and 0.

If not an exception, then I would have expected that the tile bounds to be "rolled" back to a -180/180° degree range.

I simply find this behaviour surprising, I'm aware of how I can work around this in my own code.

Backing out the above result into a Tile again:

```python
list(mercantile.tiles(-3420.0, -85.0511287798066, 3780.0, 85.0511287798066, [0]))
# [Tile(x=0, y=0, z=0)]
```

items.title: Giving `fid=0` to `feature` gets overwritten.
items.body:
In line [496](https://github.com/mapbox/mercantile/blob/5821d09ca20709e28b49aa2ea069f42acca27bb6/mercantile/__init__.py#L496) of `__init__.py`, it sets `feat['id']` to `fid` if `fid` is truthy.  This prevents you from passing in an `fid=0`, which would be natural from an `enumerate`.  The condition should be `if fid is None:`, I think.

Happy to send over a PR to fix this if you want.

items.title: Mercantile.tiles overshoots given the bounds of a tile
items.body:
If you feed the bounds of a given tile into `mercantile.tiles`, it returns four tiles:

```python
# get a tile
m = mercantile.Tile(76669,98727,18)
# get the tiles that cover the tile's bounds
list(mercantile.tiles(*mercantile.bounds(m), [18]))
```

```
 [Tile(x=76669, y=98727, z=18),
 Tile(x=76669, y=98728, z=18),
 Tile(x=76670, y=98727, z=18),
 Tile(x=76670, y=98728, z=18)]
```

items.title: Spurious Travis failures when deploying
items.body:
In releasing 1.0.1 [today](https://travis-ci.org/mapbox/mercantile/builds/341966900) I saw that the 2.7 build passed (sdist and wheel uploaded successfully to PyPI), the 3.4 build failed (wheel uploaded successfully, but source dist was already on PyPI), and the 3.5 and 3.6 builds failed because PyPI (rightfully) refuses to take duplicate uploads.

It worked out: we got an sdist and Python 2 and 3 wheels on PyPI, but I'd like to avoid the failed builds and notifications.

items.title: Error in documentation for bounding_tile
items.body:
Documentation for `mercantile.bounding_tile` states that the inputs have to be ordered as "South west east north"

https://github.com/mapbox/mercantile/blob/cd610ddbdf5910d3a68d8af8656a5c97575b66b5/mercantile/__init__.py#L387

instead in the tests and by using the code it is pretty evident that the order is "West south east north".

items.title: geojson.io example needs fix?
items.body:
The final example in the [command line](https://github.com/mapbox/mercantile/blob/master/docs/cli.rst) docs seems to throw an error.

```
$ echo "[-105, 39.99, -104.99, 40]" \
> | mercantile tiles 14 \
> | mercantile shapes --compact \
> | geojsonio
# SyntaxError: Unexpected token { in JSON at position 399..
```
which can be fixed by using geojsonify
```
$ npm install -g geojsonify
$ echo "[-105, 39.99, -104.99, 40]" \
| mercantile tiles 14 \
| mercantile shapes --compact \
| geojsonify \
| geojsonio
```
in the second, slightly updated, example I have removed the `>` characters because I think it makes it easier to read, and easier to copy and paste into a terminal.

items.title: Mercantile CLI "tiles" errors when given GeoJSON with whitespace as an input
items.body:
This command succeeds:

```bash
$ echo "[106, 193, 9]" | mercantile shapes | mercantile tiles 10
[212, 386, 10]
[212, 387, 10]
[213, 386, 10]
[213, 387, 10]
```

This fails:

```bash
$ echo "[106, 193, 9]" | mercantile shapes --indent 2 | mercantile tiles 10
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting property name enclosed in double quotes: line 2 column 1 (char 2)
```

For anyone coming across this error with GeoJSON "in the wild", my current workaround is to use `tr` to remove the whitespace:

```bash
$ echo "[106, 193, 9]" | mercantile shapes --indent 2 | tr -d " \t\n\r" | mercantile tiles 10
[212, 386, 10]
[212, 387, 10]
[213, 386, 10]
[213, 387, 10]
```

items.title: mercantile tiles gives incorrect results for points
items.body:
At any zoom level, a point can only intersect a single tile. The help text of `mercantile tiles` claims to take "lng/lat point, bounding box, or GeoJSON objects". But the results are incorrect for points.

```
$ echo '{"type":"geometry","coordinates":[14.0859, 5.798]}' | mercantile tiles 5 | wc -l
      33
$ echo "[14.0859, 5.798]" | mercantile tiles 5 | wc -l
      33
```

If we create a tiny bounding box using the point coordinate, we get the correct results.

```
$ echo "[14.0859, 5.798, 14.0860, 5.799]" | mercantile tiles 5 | wc -l
       1
```

items.title: mercantile.tile gives incorrect results with global extents
items.body:
```
>>> import mercantile

>>> list(mercantile.tiles(-180, -85, 180, 85, [1]))
[Tile(x=0, y=0, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=1, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=0, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=1, z=1)]

>>> list(mercantile.tiles(-180, -90, 180, 90, [1]))
[Tile(x=0, y=-12, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-11, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-10, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-9, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-8, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-7, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-6, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-5, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-4, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-3, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-2, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=-1, z=1), Tile(x=0, y=0, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-12, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-11, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-10, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-9, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-8, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-7, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-6, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-5, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-4, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-3, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-2, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=-1, z=1), Tile(x=1, y=0, z=1)]
```

Not sure what the correct behavior is in this case.

items.title: Extract core function of mercantile-shapes
Separate mercantile-tiles and --bounding-tile
items.body: These are actually rather different features.

items.title: Return the tiles at a zoom level that cover a feature
items.body: Tiles() returns the tiles that cover a feature's bounding box. This is more particular. I've already implemented Bresenham's algorithm elsewhere. I'll repurpose it here so that we can get a sequence of tiles at a zoom level that cover a feature.

items.title: 0.8.2 release
items.body: Bug fixes.

items.title: 0.8.1 Release
items.body: Bug fix.

items.title: Emulate JS >>>
items.body: So we get the same results as tilebelt, eg [0,0,0] bounding tiles for things that cross the antimeridian.

items.title: Streamline CLI options
items.body:
JSON Sequence is being finalized, so I'm going to alias `--x-json-seq` to `--seq`. Additionally, I'm going to alias `--extent` to `--bbox`, which is more like the Fiona and Rasterio CLI.

Furthermore, I'm going to make sequences the default for mercantile-shapes. To get a feature collection instead, use `--collect`. I've done a GitHub survey of mercantile users and don't see anything that will be broken by this change.

items.title: 0.7.1 Release
items.body: So that `mercantile tiles --bounding-tile` reproduces tilebelt's results.

items.title: Customization of shape id
items.body: As in #30, allow customization of the output feature id.

items.title: 0.7 Release
items.body: New features.

items.title: Allow setting of shape properties
items.body: Let's extend mercantile so that it can accept not only `[x, y, z]` tile arrays but `{"tile": [x, y, z], "properties": {...}}` objects. Output shapes would get the input properties attached to them. If the properties dict has a "title" item it will override the default.

items.title: Make truncation optional
items.body: Currently, mercantile truncates bounding boxes and points to keep them within the limits of the globe: [-180,-90, 180, 90]. Possible cases for not truncating, at least at the antimeridian, are cropping up, eg, https://github.com/mapbox/cardboard/issues/87. Making the truncation optional may be useful.

items.title: 0.6.1 release

items.title: converting tiles between zoom levels behaves unexpectedly
items.body:
@sgillies just ran into unexpected behavior when piping output of mercantile shapes back into mercantile tiles:

I was intending to take the zoom 12 tile, grab the $z level tiles within it, and pipe each through mercantile shapes again:

``` sh
mercantile shapes '[2331,1185,12]' | mercantile tiles 13 # | dosomething
```

But mercantile tiles output 6 zoom 13 tiles instead of the four I expected:

```
[4662, 2370, 13]
[4662, 2371, 13]
[4663, 2370, 13]
[4663, 2371, 13]
[4664, 2370, 13]
[4664, 2371, 13]
```

Is this expected/desired behavior?

items.title: Transfer to Mapbox
items.body: Hey @steko, any objection to me moving this to the Mapbox org? There would be no changes in license or anything? The move would be just to lower barriers to use at Mapbox, which is really the only place I employ the package.

items.title: Add features of tilebelt
items.body:
Mercantile is the natural place for features like these:
- [x] get the tile for a point at a particular zoom super fast
- [x] get the 4 tiles below a particular tile
- [x] get the tile one zoom up from a particular tile

items.title: Check gdalwarp using mercantile shapes --mercator (no CRS) as cutline
items.body: Follow up from https://github.com/sgillies/mercantile/issues/14#issuecomment-52943376.

items.title: Check mercantile tiles --mercator against ogr2ogr
items.body:
Comparison:

`mercantile shapes $TILE --mercator` 

vs 

```
mercantile shapes $TILE --geographic \
| ogr2ogr -f "GeoJSON" -s_srs EPSG:4326 -t_srs EPSG:3857 /vsistdout/ /vsistdin/
```

items.title: Add CRS to geojson output
items.body:
Add the CRS info to the geojson output.

Currently the workaround is this:

``` sh
mercantile shapes - --x-json-seq  --mercator | \
sed -E 's/\}$/,"crs": \{"type": "EPSG","properties": \{"code": 3857 \}\}\}/g'
```

cc @hrwgc

items.title: Buffer a region
items.body:
When tiling and processing adjacent images, it is often needed to buffer these cutlines. It would be great to have an option to buffer directly with mercantile.

Currently we are buffering using this, which is not ideal:

``` sh
width=10
bbox=(`ogrinfo -al  $cutline.geojson 2>&1 | grep Extent | sed -E "s/[^0-9\.\-]+/ /g;s/ - / /g"`)
bufferedbbox="`echo ${bbox[0]}-$width | bc -l` `echo ${bbox[1]}-$width | bc -l` `echo ${bbox[2]}+$width | bc -l` `echo ${bbox[3]}+$width | bc -l`"
```

cc @hrwgc

items.title: Transparent handling of file, stream, and text input
items.body: As in geomet.

items.title: 0.3 release
items.body: To get the --mercator option and new README out there.

items.title: Add option for Mercator output
items.body: Bypassing WGS84.

items.title: Accept mercator bounds as well as geographic
items.body: Something like `mercantile tiles - 9 --mercator` should work.

items.title: Add --collection option to CLI tiles command
items.body: Retroactively added. Document this next.

items.title: Roll mercantile.tool command into mercantile script
0.2 release
items.body: To go with Rasterio 0.11.1. See https://github.com/mapbox/rasterio/issues/125.

items.title: Link to node-sphericalmercator?
items.body:
This is kind of similar to [node-sphericalmercator](https://github.com/mapbox/node-sphericalmercator), just very cool. I've added it to the See Also for that project, maybe it should go both ways?

(See Also sections are kind of an experiment, so that might not be up your alley. The jist is that they provide known connections between good code that does similar stuff)

items.title: Add script to get tiles from input bbox
items.body:
See https://github.com/mapbox/rasterio/issues/124.

```
$ echo "[$west, $south, $east, $north]" | mercantile tiles --zoom 9
X1, Y1, W1, S1, E1, N1
X2, Y2, W2, S2, E2, N2
...
```
